The presence of cell surface caveolin/caveolae has been postulated to influence the localization, expression levels, and kinase activity of numerous receptors, including the insulin receptor. However, there are conflicting data concerning the effects of caveolin on insulin receptor expression and function. To help clarify this issue, we created a gain of function situation by expressing caveolin-1 at various levels in HEK-293 cells where the endogenous level of caveolin-1 is very low. We generated four permanent lines of this cell expressing amounts of caveolin-1 ranging from 10 to 40 times that of parental cells. The amount of caveolin-1 in the human embryonic kidney cells expressing the highest caveolin levels is comparable with that of adipocytes, cells that naturally express one of the highest levels of caveolin-1. We measured insulin receptor amount and insulin-dependent receptor autophosphorylation as well as insulin receptor substrate 1 (IRS1) tyrosine phosphorylation as an index of insulin signaling. We found that the insulin receptor level was essentially the same in the parental and all four derived cell lines. Likewise, we determined that insulin-dependent insulin receptor and IRS1 tyrosine phosphorylation was not significantly different in the four cell lines representing parental, low, medium, and high levels of caveolin-1 expression. We conclude that insulin receptor expression and ligand-dependent signaling is independent of caveolin-1 expression. The presence of cell surface caveolin/caveolae has been postulated to influence the localization, expression levels, and kinase activity of numerous receptors, including the insulin receptor. However, there are conflicting data concerning the effects of caveolin on insulin receptor expression and function. To help clarify this issue, we created a gain of function situation by expressing caveolin-1 at various levels in HEK-293 cells where the endogenous level of caveolin-1 is very low. We generated four permanent lines of this cell expressing amounts of caveolin-1 ranging from 10 to 40 times that of parental cells. The amount of caveolin-1 in the human embryonic kidney cells expressing the highest caveolin levels is comparable with that of adipocytes, cells that naturally express one of the highest levels of caveolin-1. We measured insulin receptor amount and insulin-dependent receptor autophosphorylation as well as insulin receptor substrate 1 (IRS1) tyrosine phosphorylation as an index of insulin signaling. We found that the insulin receptor level was essentially the same in the parental and all four derived cell lines. Likewise, we determined that insulin-dependent insulin receptor and IRS1 tyrosine phosphorylation was not significantly different in the four cell lines representing parental, low, medium, and high levels of caveolin-1 expression. We conclude that insulin receptor expression and ligand-dependent signaling is independent of caveolin-1 expression. Caveolae are 50–100 nm invaginations of the plasma membrane that project into the cytosol, and they have been postulated to play numerous important physiological roles in a variety of cell types (1.Cohen A.W. Hnasko R. Schubert W. Lisanti M.P. Physiol. Rev. 2004; 84: 1341-1379Crossref PubMed Scopus (721) Google Scholar). These postulated caveolae-mediated functions include a role in vesicular transport via endocytosis/transcytosis in the endothelium and other tissues (2.Rothberg K.G. Heuser J.E. Donzell W.C. Ying Y.S. Glenney J.R. Anderson R.G. Cell. 1992; 68: 673-682Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1860) Google Scholar, 3.Schnitzer J.E. Oh P. Pinney E. Allard J. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 127: 1217-1232Crossref PubMed Scopus (770) Google Scholar, 4.Schnitzer J.E. Liu J. Oh P. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 14399-14404Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (325) Google Scholar, 5.Oh P. McIntosh D.P. Schnitzer J.E. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 141: 101-114Crossref PubMed Scopus (553) Google Scholar, 6.Henley J.R. Krueger E.W. Oswald B.J. McNiven M.A. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 141: 85-99Crossref PubMed Scopus (618) Google Scholar) and a role as an organizational scaffold for numerous receptors and the components of their signal transduction pathways in a large number of tissues (7.Smart E.J. Graf G.A. McNiven M.A. Sessa W.C. Engelman J.A. Scherer P.E. Okamoto T. Lisanti M.P. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 7289-7304Crossref PubMed Scopus (918) Google Scholar). An important biochemical feature of caveolae is that they are enriched in free cholesterol by virtue of the fact that caveolin-1 is a cholesterol-binding protein (8.Fielding C.J. Fielding P.E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1529: 210-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (186) Google Scholar). Caveolae are particularly abundant in adipocytes (9.Fan J.Y. Carpentier J.L. van Obberghen E. Grunfeld C. Gorden P. Orci L. J. Cell Sci. 1983; 61: 219-230Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), where they have been postulated to serve as a major site for the initiation of insulin signaling (10.Baumann C.A. Ribon V. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Mora S. Shigematsu S. Bickel P.E. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2000; 407: 202-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (556) Google Scholar). This is a controversial finding, as insulin receptors have been found to be localized in adipocyte caveolae and/or associate with caveolin by some investigators (11.Gustavsson J. Parpal S. Karlsson M. Ramsing C. Thorn H. Borg M. Lindroth M. Peterson K.H. Magnusson K.E. Stralfors P. FASEB J. 1999; 13: 1961-1971Crossref PubMed Scopus (315) Google Scholar, 12.Kimura A. Mora S. Shigematsu S. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 30153-30158Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar) but not others (13.Mastick C.C. Brady M.J. Saltiel A.R. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 129: 1523-1531Crossref PubMed Scopus (199) Google Scholar, 14.Souto R.P. Vallega G. Wharton J. Vinten J. Tranum-Jensen J. Pilch P.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 18321-18329Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). Also, caveolin/caveolae have been suggested to play a role in the regulation of insulin signaling by affecting the phosphorylation of insulin receptor substrate 1 (IRS1) 1The abbreviations used are: IRS1, insulin receptor substrate 1; IR, insulin receptor; HEK, human embryonic kidney; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline. 1The abbreviations used are: IRS1, insulin receptor substrate 1; IR, insulin receptor; HEK, human embryonic kidney; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline. (15.Yamamoto M. Toya Y. Schwencke C. Lisanti M.P. Myers Jr., M.G. Ishikawa Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26962-26968Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar). Caveolin-1 knock-out animals have been generated that are viable despite vascular abnormalities and, interestingly, have abnormal adipocytes and develop insulin resistance as they age (16.Razani B. Combs T.P. Wang X.B. Frank P.G. Park D.S. Russell R.G. Li M. Tang B. Jelicks L.A. Scherer P.E. Lisanti M.P. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 8635-8647Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (460) Google Scholar). Consequently, Lisanti and colleagues have generated adipocytes from caveolin-1 null fibroblasts in order to better understand the phenotype of the caveolin-1 null animals with regard to their insulin responsiveness and the development of insulin resistance (17.Cohen A.W. Razani B. Wang X.B. Combs T.P. Williams T.M. Scherer P.E. Lisanti M.P. Am. J. Physiol. 2003; 285: C222-C235Crossref PubMed Scopus (276) Google Scholar). They found that such adipocytes had reduced insulin receptor levels compared with those of wild type, and they showed that these levels could be restored to normal levels by transfection of caveolin-1. They also determined that this relationship between insulin receptor levels and caveolin might be a more general phenomenon by showing that transient transfection of caveolin-1 in HEK-293 cells leads to an up-regulation of insulin receptor expression (17.Cohen A.W. Razani B. Wang X.B. Combs T.P. Williams T.M. Scherer P.E. Lisanti M.P. Am. J. Physiol. 2003; 285: C222-C235Crossref PubMed Scopus (276) Google Scholar). However, in similar experimental protocols other investigators have not observed a relationship between caveolin expression and insulin receptor amounts (15.Yamamoto M. Toya Y. Schwencke C. Lisanti M.P. Myers Jr., M.G. Ishikawa Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26962-26968Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar). Caveolae are thought to be formed by the tissue-specific expression of three caveolin isoforms (caveolin-1, -2, and -3), and they can be induced to form in tissues lacking caveolae by the ectopic expression of caveolin-1, for example (18.Fra A.M. Williamson E. Simons K. Parton R.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 8655-8659Crossref PubMed Scopus (525) Google Scholar, 19.Lipardi C. Mora R. Colomer V. Paladino S. Nitsch L. Rodriguez-Boulan E. Zurzolo C. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 140: 617-626Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). The human embryonic kidney cell line, HEK-293, expresses low to negligible levels of caveolin-1 (20.Wang L. Connelly M.A. Ostermeyer A.G. Chen H.H. Williams D.L. Brown D.A. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 807-815Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Thus, we sought to help clarify the relationship of insulin receptor expression/function to that of caveolin-1 expression by creating a number of permanent HEK cell lines with levels of caveolin-1 varying from undetectable to approximately that found in adipocytes. We then determined insulin receptor expression levels and ligand-dependent function. Antibodies and Western Blotting—Antibodies to caveolin-1, flotillin-1, and phosphotyrosine PY20 were obtained from BD Transduction Laboratories. The anti-phosphotyrosine antibody 4G10 was purchased from Upstate Biotechnologies, Lake Placid, NY. Anti-insulin receptor (21.Kublaoui B. Lee J. Pilch P.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 59-65Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar) and anti-IRS1 antibodies were kindly provided by Dr. Jongsoon Lee of the Joslin Diabetes Center, Harvard Medical School. Following SDS-PAGE (22.Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (206597) Google Scholar), primary antibodies were detected using appropriate secondary antibodies obtained from Sigma and conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (Sigma) and a chemiluminescence substrate (PerkinElmer Life Sciences). Quantitative analysis of gel bands was performed by scanning blots with the NIH Image 1.63 software program. Generation of HEK-293 Cell Lines—Mouse caveolin-1α cDNA was produced by reverse transcription PCR from 3T3-L1 adipocytes. The cDNA was then inserted into the pcDNA3.1 Hygro vector and transfected into HEK-293 cells using Lipofectamine 2000 (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Single colonies were selected using cloning rings (Falcon, Franklin Lakes, NJ), and each line of HEK-293 cells produced was tested for levels of caveolin-1 expression. Four cell lines were developed from this procedure, each with different expression levels of caveolin-1. The five cell lines used, ranging from those with little to no expression of caveolin-1 to those with high expression of caveolin-1, are parent, D20, D7, A4, and B8 (see Fig. 1). The HEK-293 cell lines expressing different levels of caveolin-1 were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's media (Mediatech Inc., Herndon, VA) containing a mixture of penicillin (5000 units/ml) and streptomycin (5000 μg/ml) (Invitrogen). The media were supplemented with 5% fetal bovine serum (Hyclone, Logan, UT), and 5% calf serum (Invitrogen). Isolation of Cell Membranes—A postnuclear membrane preparation from the HEK-293 cells was obtained using the method described previously (23.Schlegel A. Schwab R.B. Scherer P.E. Lisanti M.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22660-22667Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar). Briefly, cell lines were grown to confluence, scraped into cold PBS (137 mm NaCl, 2.7 mm KCl, 10 mm Na2HPO4, 1.8 mm KH2PO4 and 5 mm benzamidine), and pelleted by centrifugation at 1000 × g. The cells were resuspended in hypotonic buffer (5 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 1 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EGTA, and 0.1 mm EDTA) supplemented with protease inhibitors, 1 μm aprotinin, 10 μm leupeptin, 1 μm pepstatin, and 5 mm benzamidine. The lysates were incubated on ice for 30 min and passed through a 21-gauge needle 10 times and centrifuged at 1000 × g to remove nuclear debris. The postnuclear lysate was then centrifuged at 133,000 × g for 30 min. The membrane pellet was resuspended in PBS with the protease inhibitors noted above. An adipocyte plasma membrane was obtained following the enzymatic isolation of epididymal fat pads as we have described (14.Souto R.P. Vallega G. Wharton J. Vinten J. Tranum-Jensen J. Pilch P.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 18321-18329Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar), following the protocol of Simpson et al. (24.Simpson I.A. Yver D.R. Hissin P.J. Wardzala L.J. Karnieli E. Salans L.B. Cushman S.W. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1983; 763: 393-407Crossref PubMed Scopus (330) Google Scholar). Protein concentration was estimated using a BCA kit (Pierce). Cholesterol Determination—The assays were performed as outlined previously (25.Tercyak A. J. Nutr. Biochem. 1991; 2: 282-292Crossref Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Briefly, total and free cholesterol were determined by extracting lipids from HEK cells by the Folch method (26.Folch J. Lees M. Sloane Stanley G.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1957; 226: 497-509Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The lipid phase was hydrolyzed by KOH and ethanol, and a colorimetric assay was used for quantitative analysis. Immunoprecipitation—Immunoprecipitation was performed for the insulin receptor (IR) (21.Kublaoui B. Lee J. Pilch P.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 59-65Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar) and IRS1 (27.Whiteman E.L. Birnbaum M.J. Methods Mol. Med. 2003; 83: 119-126PubMed Google Scholar) as described in the respective references. Cell membranes (IR) or cell lysates (IRS1) were incubated in buffer (30 mm Hepes and 150 mm NaCl supplemented with 3 μm aprotinin, 10 μm leupeptin, 5 μm pepstatin, 5 mm benzamidine, 100 mm NaF, 2 mm Na3VO4, 20 mm tetrasodium pyrophosphate, 1 mm ammonium molybdate, 5 mm β-glycerolphosphate, 30 mm tetrasodium pyrophosphate, and 5 mm EGTA, all adjusted to pH 7.4) containing 0.1% Triton X-100 and an anti-IR or anti-IRS1 antibody for 1 h at 4 °C, followed by a 1-h incubation with protein G-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences) at 4 °C. Pellets were washed and eluted with 1× Laemmli sample buffer containing 2% SDS and 5% β-mercaptoethanol. Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE. Blots were probed with a mixture of 4G10 and PY20 or anti-IR and anti-IRS1. Immunofluorescence—HEK cells were grown in 6-well tissue culture plates containing poly-l-lysine-coated coverslips (BD Biosciences) for 48 h. Cells were then washed one time with PBS and fixed with 3.7% formaldehyde in PBS for 15 min at room temperature and then washed two more times with PBS. Cells were blocked and permeabilized by incubation with buffer P (5% donkey serum (Sigma), 5% bovine serum albumin, and 0.5% Triton X-100 in PBS) for 20 min at room temperature. The fixed cells were incubated for 2 h with rabbit anti-caveolin-1 antibody at a dilution of 1:250 in buffer P at room temperature. Four more washes with buffer P were then performed, and the cells were covered in aluminum foil and incubated for 30 min at room temperature with an anti-rabbit Cy3 secondary antibody (Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratories, Inc., West Grove PA) at a dilution of 1:250. Again, the cells were washed four times with PBS and then mounted with a glycerol/PBS solution (component A of the SlowFade antifade kit from Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR). The stained cells were observed with a Zeiss Axiovert 200M microscope equipped with a Hamamatsu Photonics camera for standard immunofluorescence. Fig. 1A shows, by Western blotting, the expression levels of caveolin-1, the insulin receptor, and the lipid raft protein flotillin in parental HEK cells and in four cell lines transfected with caveolin-1 cDNA and then selected for different levels of caveolin-1 expression. Caveolin-1 expression varies from 10- to 40-fold higher in these four cell lines than in the parental cells (Fig. 1B), which contain barely detectable levels of caveolin. On the other hand, the insulin receptor levels are essentially the same in all five cell lines, as is the expression of flotillin (Fig. 1, A and B), which was included as a control for the possible effects of caveolin-1 expression on another protein known to be a component of lipid rafts (28.Bickel P.E. Scherer P.E. Schnitzer J.E. Oh P. Lisanti M.P. Lodish H.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 13793-13802Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (493) Google Scholar). To determine the localization of expressed caveolin-1, immunofluorescence was performed using an anti-caveolin-1 antibody. Fig. 2 shows the immunofluorescence of HEK cell line B8 expressing a relatively high level of caveolin-1 as compared with that of parental HEK cells. The caveolin-1-expressing HEK cell line, B8, shows expression of caveolin-1 on the surface of cells, whereas the parental HEK cells show no detectable caveolin-1 expression by this technique. To determine whether there was a functional consequence of caveolin-1 expression in the transfected cells, we measured free cholesterol as shown in Table I. All transfected cells show increased free cholesterol with the two highest expressers exhibiting a statistically significant 78 and 69% increase, respectively, in free cholesterol as compared with the parental cell line. Because caveolin-1 is a cholesterol-binding protein (8.Fielding C.J. Fielding P.E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2000; 1529: 210-222Crossref PubMed Scopus (186) Google Scholar) and free cholesterol is predominantly present at the plasma membrane (29.Pichler H. Riezman H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2004; 1666: 51-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar), these results are consistent with expectations and with the caveolin-1 fluorescence data of Fig. 2.Table IFree cholesterol content of HEK cellsCell lineFree cholesterolμg/mg proteinParental23.7 ± 2.1D2026.4 ± 1.0D726.6 ± 2.3A442.3 ± 3.9ap < 0.05; Student's t test.B840.1 ± 6.5ap < 0.05; Student's t test.a p < 0.05; Student's t test. Open table in a new tab We next determined if the level of caveolin-1 in HEK cells expressing the highest amount of caveolin-1 was comparable with caveolin levels in adipocytes, the cell type in which most studies of the relationship between insulin receptors and caveolae have been performed. Using Western blotting with an anti-caveolin-1 antibody, we compared total membrane preparations from the HEK cells with a rat adipocyte plasma membrane preparation. As shown in Fig. 3, caveolin-1 expression in a 25-μg sample from HEK cells is the same as that in a 5-μg sample from rat adipocytes. The purity of the membrane preparation with regard to cell surface markers is >90% for adipocytes (24.Simpson I.A. Yver D.R. Hissin P.J. Wardzala L.J. Karnieli E. Salans L.B. Cushman S.W. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1983; 763: 393-407Crossref PubMed Scopus (330) Google Scholar) and ∼30% for the HEK cells shown. This corresponds to cell surface caveolin-1 levels in the HEK cell line B8 that are at least 60% of that in adipocytes; in other words, a high level of caveolin-1 expression is consistent with its possible biochemical/physiological significance. We measured receptor autophosphorylation following cellular exposure to insulin in four of the cell lines corresponding to low, medium, and high levels of caveolin-1 expression, as well as in the parental cells. As shown in Fig. 4, following immunoprecipitation of phosphorylated receptor and blotting with an anti-phosphotyrosine antibody, there are no significant differences in receptor autophosphorylation in the cell lines tested and no differences in the overall levels of the insulin receptor (see also Fig. 1). Finally, we measured insulin-dependent phosphorylation of IRS1 to determine whether downstream receptor signaling was affected by caveolin as has been suggested (15.Yamamoto M. Toya Y. Schwencke C. Lisanti M.P. Myers Jr., M.G. Ishikawa Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26962-26968Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar). Again we found this not to be the case (Fig. 5), indicating that the cell surface kinase activity of the receptor was not affected by any presumptive interaction with caveolin-1.Fig. 5Insulin-dependent IRS1 tyrosine phosphorylation is the same in cells expressing different levels of caveolin-1. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 20163-20166Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Consequently, the putative association of caveolin with and phosphorylation by other non-receptor and receptor tyrosine kinases has been described in many studies (reviewed in Ref. 31.Pike L.J. J. Lipid Res. 2003; 44: 655-667Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (941) Google Scholar). The association of non-receptor tyrosine kinases of the Src family with lipid raft domains, including caveolae, is likely to be a result of their myristoylation, which allows their association with relatively structured lipid raft membrane domains, whereas the transmembrane sequences of receptor tyrosine kinases are likely to be excluded from lipid rafts such as caveolae, as has been predicted by studies of model systems (32.Fastenberg M.E. Shogomori H. Xu X. Brown D.A. London E. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 12376-12390Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Indeed, in cultured adipocytes, which express robust levels of caveolin-1, the tyrosine phosphorylation of caveolin-1 observed upon activation of the insulin receptor was first described as indirect and resulting from the action of Fyn, a member of the Src kinase family, and not directly by insulin receptors (13.Mastick C.C. Brady M.J. Saltiel A.R. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 129: 1523-1531Crossref PubMed Scopus (199) Google Scholar). This paper describes cell fractionation protocols to biochemically purify caveolae and reports that the majority of the insulin receptor was excluded from the “floating” fraction of the caveolae enriched in caveolin (13.Mastick C.C. Brady M.J. Saltiel A.R. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 129: 1523-1531Crossref PubMed Scopus (199) Google Scholar). However, this result was reassessed by some of the same investigators who subsequently reached the opposite conclusion that the interaction of caveolin and the insulin receptor was direct based on their co-fractionation in discontinuous sucrose gradients (12.Kimura A. Mora S. Shigematsu S. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 30153-30158Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar). Additional biochemical and/or morphological studies in adipocytes have also provided conflicting results favoring or not favoring a direct interaction between caveolae and the insulin receptor. Morphological (electron microscopy) and biochemical analysis of rat adipocytes suggested the co-localization of insulin receptor with caveolae (11.Gustavsson J. Parpal S. Karlsson M. Ramsing C. Thorn H. Borg M. Lindroth M. Peterson K.H. Magnusson K.E. Stralfors P. FASEB J. 1999; 13: 1961-1971Crossref PubMed Scopus (315) Google Scholar). On the other hand, we also used both electron microscopy and an immunoaffinity protocol to rapidly isolate caveolae, and we did not detect any insulin receptor in caveolae by either method (14.Souto R.P. Vallega G. Wharton J. Vinten J. Tranum-Jensen J. Pilch P.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 18321-18329Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). We speculate that the reasons for these discrepancies in biochemical analysis most likely lie in the methods used in these various studies, as we have discussed in detail (14.Souto R.P. Vallega G. Wharton J. Vinten J. Tranum-Jensen J. Pilch P.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 18321-18329Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). That is, the time and manipulations required in many protocols of caveolae isolation are factors that are likely to produce artifacts concerning caveolae protein content. The discrepancies in the morphological results are more difficult to explain, although the association of membrane proteins with caveolae can be an artifact of the techniques used (33.Maxfield F.R. Mayor S. Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. 1997; 419: 355-364Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Moreover, the observation that transmembrane sequences such as those found in the insulin receptor do not partition into the lipid raft domains characteristic of caveolae (32.Fastenberg M.E. Shogomori H. Xu X. Brown D.A. London E. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 12376-12390Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar), and the observation that caveolae are non-dynamic structures (34.Thomsen P. Roepstorff K. Stahlhut M. van Deurs B. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2002; 13: 238-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (373) Google Scholar) in the time frame of the trafficking/endocytosis of the insulin receptor through clathrin-coated pits (14.Souto R.P. Vallega G. Wharton J. Vinten J. Tranum-Jensen J. Pilch P.F. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 18321-18329Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar, 35.Pilch P.F. Shia M.A. Benson R.J. Fine R.E. J. Cell Biol. 1983; 96: 133-138Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar, 36.Wiley H.S. Burke P.M. Traffic. 2001; 2: 12-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar) makes it seem unlikely to us that adipocyte insulin receptors are localized or associate with caveolae Nevertheless, as an independent means addressing the relationship between caveolin-1 and insulin receptors independent of adipocytes, experiments have been performed in cell lines where one can alter the amount of caveolin-1 and determine the functional consequences, if any, of these alterations for signaling from the insulin receptor. In this context, the recent report by Cohen et al. (17.Cohen A.W. Razani B. Wang X.B. Combs T.P. Williams T.M. Scherer P.E. Lisanti M.P. Am. J. Physiol. 2003; 285: C222-C235Crossref PubMed Scopus (276) Google Scholar) documenting effects of caveolin-1 expression on insulin receptor levels was surprising. These investigators showed that insulin receptor levels are diminished in an adipocyte cell line derived from caveolin-1 null animals but that the receptor levels could be increased by the re-introduction of caveolin-1. We have measured the levels of insulin receptors and caveolin-1 in various adipocyte cell lines such as those described in Refs. 37.El-Jack A.K. Hamm J.K. Pilch P.F. Farmer S.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 7946-7951Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar and 38.Gross D.N. Farmer S.R. Pilch P.F. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2004; 24: 7151-7162Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, which express these proteins to different extents, and we see no correlation between the two (data not shown). These researchers observed similar results using HEK cells transfected with caveolin-1, albeit they employed transient transfection protocols and described a single result that confirmed their data obtained with caveolin-1 null adipocytes. On the other hand, Yamamoto et al. (15.Yamamoto M. Toya Y. Schwencke C. Lisanti M.P. Myers Jr., M.G. Ishikawa Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26962-26968Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar) previously found no effect of caveolin-3 expression on insulin receptor levels or receptor autophosphorylation in transiently transfected HEK cells but did observe a small increase in IRS1 phosphorylation in the transfected cells that they considered significant. Peptides derived from caveolins-1 and -3 were also found to stimulate insulin-dependent IRS1 phosphorylation. These authors (15.Yamamoto M. Toya Y. Schwencke C. Lisanti M.P. Myers Jr., M.G. Ishikawa Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 26962-26968Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar) attributed these results to a direct interaction of caveolin with the insulin receptor's kinase domain. However, the receptor sequences they mapped as interacting with caveolin are not obviously accessible to other proteins based on the crystal structure of the kinase domain (39.Hubbard S.R. Wei L. Ellis L. Hendrickson W.A. Nature. 1994; 372: 746-754Crossref PubMed Scopus (954) Google Scholar), thus clouding the interpretation of these studies. Thus, we report here the use of four stable cell lines expressing caveolin-1 at various levels, the highest two approaching that seen in adipocytes. The insulin receptor amount and ligand-dependent activation of its kinase activity, as well as the phosphorylation of its major substrate IRS1, is essentially the same in all of the cell lines and in the non-transfected parental cells. As noted previously, there is no obvious reason why caveolin levels should effect the expression of insulin receptors. These receptors are highly expressed and function perfectly well in the important insulin target cells of the liver where caveolin expression is minimal (40.Vainio S. Heino S. Mansson J.E. Fredman P. Kuismanen E. Vaarala O. Ikonen E. EMBO Rep. 2002; 3: 95-100Crossref PubMed Scopus (140) Google Scholar). We conclude that caveolin-1 expression has no effect on insulin receptor expression or function as determined by gain of function experiments in HEK cells, and, for reasons noted above, we believe this is likely to be true for the real insulin target cells of fat and muscle. We thank Dr. Jongsoon Lee, Joslin Diabetes Center, Boston, MA for reagents and help with immunoprecipitation assays.

In this paper, we show that in vitro xanthosine does not enter any of the pathways known to salvage the other three main natural purine nucleosides: guanosine; inosine; and adenosine. In rat brain extracts and in intact LoVo cells, xanthosine is salvaged to XMP via the phosphotransferase activity of cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase. IMP is the preferred phosphate donor (IMP + xanthosine → XMP + inosine). XMP is not further phosphorylated. However, in the presence of glutamine, it is readily converted to guanyl compounds. Thus, phosphorylation of xanthosine by cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase circumvents the activity of IMP dehydrogenase, a rate-limiting enzyme, catalyzing the NAD+-dependent conversion of IMP to XMP at the branch point of de novo nucleotide synthesis, thus leading to the generation of guanine nucleotides. Mycophenolic acid, an inhibitor of IMP dehydrogenase, inhibits the guanyl compound synthesis via the IMP dehydrogenase pathway but has no effect on the cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase pathway of guanine nucleotides synthesis. We propose that the latter pathway might contribute to the reversal of the in vitro antiproliferative effect exerted by IMP dehydrogenase inhibitors routinely seen with repletion of the guanine nucleotide pools. In this paper, we show that in vitro xanthosine does not enter any of the pathways known to salvage the other three main natural purine nucleosides: guanosine; inosine; and adenosine. In rat brain extracts and in intact LoVo cells, xanthosine is salvaged to XMP via the phosphotransferase activity of cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase. IMP is the preferred phosphate donor (IMP + xanthosine → XMP + inosine). XMP is not further phosphorylated. However, in the presence of glutamine, it is readily converted to guanyl compounds. Thus, phosphorylation of xanthosine by cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase circumvents the activity of IMP dehydrogenase, a rate-limiting enzyme, catalyzing the NAD+-dependent conversion of IMP to XMP at the branch point of de novo nucleotide synthesis, thus leading to the generation of guanine nucleotides. Mycophenolic acid, an inhibitor of IMP dehydrogenase, inhibits the guanyl compound synthesis via the IMP dehydrogenase pathway but has no effect on the cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase pathway of guanine nucleotides synthesis. We propose that the latter pathway might contribute to the reversal of the in vitro antiproliferative effect exerted by IMP dehydrogenase inhibitors routinely seen with repletion of the guanine nucleotide pools. A wealth of in vitro and in vivo evidence supports the idea that some cell types and districts, such as human red cells and brain, rely more heavily on the salvage pathway rather than on de novo pathway synthesis of nucleotides (1.Allsop J. Watts R.W. Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. 1984; 165: 21-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar, 2.Murray A.W. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1971; 40: 811-826Crossref PubMed Scopus (279) Google Scholar, 3.Cappiello M. Mascia L. Scolozzi C. Giorgelli F. Ipata P.L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1425: 273-281Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 4.Barsotti C. Tozzi M.G. Ipata P.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 9865-9869Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar). In addition, the salvage pathway is responsible for the activation of many purine and pyrimidine analogs to cytotoxic compounds (5.Chabner B.A. Chabner B.A. Longo D.L. Cancer Chemotherapy and Biotheraphy. Lippincot-Williams & Wilkins, Philadelphia, PA1995: 235-252Google Scholar). Even though some differences might exist among different cell types, it can be assumed that, in mammals, inosine and guanosine must undergo prior phosphorolysis by purine nucleoside phosphorylase (PNP) 1The abbreviations used are: PNP, purine nucleoside phosphorylase; HGPRT, hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase; Xao, xanthosine; cN-II, cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase; IMPDH, IMP dehydrogenase; 2,3-BPG, 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate; MPA, mycophenolic acid; DTT, dithiothreitol; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; PEI, polyethyleneimine; XMP, xanthosine 5′-monophosphate; IMP, inosine 5′-monophosphate. 1The abbreviations used are: PNP, purine nucleoside phosphorylase; HGPRT, hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase; Xao, xanthosine; cN-II, cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase; IMPDH, IMP dehydrogenase; 2,3-BPG, 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate; MPA, mycophenolic acid; DTT, dithiothreitol; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; PEI, polyethyleneimine; XMP, xanthosine 5′-monophosphate; IMP, inosine 5′-monophosphate. in order to be salvaged to their respective nucleoside monophosphates by the PRPP-mediated hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) reaction (the PNP-HGPRT pathway). Adenosine is either directly phosphorylated to AMP by a specific kinase or salvaged as inosine after deamination at low and high micromolar levels, respectively (6.Latini S. Pedata F. J. Neurochem. 2001; 79: 463-484Crossref PubMed Scopus (635) Google Scholar). No kinase activity exists for inosine and guanosine (7.Stone T.W. Simmonds H.A. Purine: Basic and Clinical Aspects. Kluwer Academic Publishers, Norwell, MA1991: 8-22Google Scholar). To our knowledge, the possible anabolic salvage route(s) of the fourth natural purine nucleoside, xanthosine (Xao), have not been equally extensively studied. Our interest on the salvage of this nucleoside was raised by recent reports (8.Gille A. Wenzel-Seifert K. Doughty M.B. Seifert R. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 7822-7828Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 9.Liu H.Y. Seifert R. Biochem. Pharmacol. 2002; 64: 583-593Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 10.Seifert R. Gether U. Wenzel-Seifert K. Kobilka B.K. Mol. Pharmacol. 1999; 56: 348-358Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar), indicating that Xao phosphates interact with β2-adrenergic G protein-coupled receptors. In this paper, we show that in vitro Xao is not phosphorylated by any ATP-mediated nucleoside kinase present in rat brain cytosolic extract. Neither can it be salvaged via the PNP-HGPRT pathway. Rather, it is anabolyzed through a new salvage synthesis where the phosphotransferase activity of the IMP-GMP-specific cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase (cN-II) (IMP + H2O → inosine + Pi) plays a pivotal role and circumvents that of IMP dehydrogenase (IMPDH). Materials—[8-14C]IMP (53 mCi/mmol), [8-14C]inosine (52 mCi/mmol), and [8-14C]Xao (55 mCi/mmol) were from Moravek Biochemicals. [8-14C]Adenosine (58 mCi/mmol), [8-14C]guanine (53.3 mCi/mmol), 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG), glutamine, mycophenolic acid (MPA), dithiothreitol (DTT), bases, nucleosides, and nucleotides were from Sigma. Ham's F-12 medium, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) without glucose, and fetal calf serum were from Invitrogen. [8-14C]Guanosine was prepared from [8-14C]guanine. 1.9 mm [8-14C]guanine (50,000 dpm/nmol) was incubated at 37 °C in the presence of 8 mm ribose 1-phosphate, 1.5 units of PNP, and 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4 in a final volume of 300 μl. After 2 h of incubation, the reaction was stopped by heating the mixture for 5 min at 100 °C. The mixture then was applied to a polyethyleneimine (PEI)-cellulose-precoated thinlayer plastic sheet and developed with 0.1 mm (NH4)2SO4. The zone corresponding to guanosine was excised and eluted with 200 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4. Cold guanosine then was added to reach a final concentration of 3.67 mm. The final [8-14C]guanosine prepared had a specific activity of 5000 dpm/nmol. Bovine recombinant cN-II was prepared as described previously (11.Allegrini S. Pesi R. Tozzi M.G. Fiol C.J. Johnson R.B. Eriksson S. Biochem. J. 1997; 328: 483-487Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The human colon carcinoma cell line, LoVo, was provided by Dr. O. Sanfilippo (Milan, Italy). Hi Safe II scintillation liquid was purchased from Wallac. PEI-cellulose-precoated thin-layer plastic sheets (0.1-mm thick) were purchased from Merck and pre-washed once with 10% NaCl and three times with deionized water before use. All of the other chemicals were of reagent grade. Preparation of Rat Brain Extracts—Three-month-old male Sprague-Dawley rats (250 g) were sacrificed by decapitation. Procedures involving animals and their care were conducted in conformity with the institutional guidelines that are in compliance with national and international laws and policies. The brains were removed and kept frozen at –80 °C until needed. Storage times did not exceed 3 months. The brain was cut in small pieces, washed with cold saline, and gently homogenized with a hand-driven Potter homogenizer in 3 volumes of 100 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 7.4, with 20 mm KCl and 1 mm DTT. The homogenate was centrifuged at 4 °C at 39,000 × g for 1 h. The supernatant fluid obtained was dialyzed overnight at 4 °C in dialysis bags against 10 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 7.4, supplemented with 1 mm DTT, and is referred to as crude extract. The preparation, which is devoid of plasma membranes, nuclei, and mitochondria, proved to be extremely useful in studies on rat brain purine and pyrimidine salvage synthesis (3.Cappiello M. Mascia L. Scolozzi C. Giorgelli F. Ipata P.L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1425: 273-281Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 4.Barsotti C. Tozzi M.G. Ipata P.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 9865-9869Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 12.Giorgelli F. Bottai C. Mascia L. Scolozzi C. Camici M. Ipata P.L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1335: 16-22Crossref Scopus (20) Google Scholar) as well as in ATP breakdown studies under conditions mimicking anoxia (13.Barsotti C. Ipata P.L. Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 2004; 36: 2214-2225Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Protein concentration was determined by the Coomassie Blue binding assay using bovine serum albumin as standard (14.Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (214515) Google Scholar). Cell Cultures and Preparation of Cell Extracts—Cells were routinely grown as a monolayer in Ham's F-12 medium with 7% fetal calf serum and antibiotics at 37 °C in a humidified 5% CO2, 95% air atmosphere (standard medium). The doubling time was 32 h. For the preparation of cell extracts, when cells were in the logarithmic phase of growth, the monolayers were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline and the cells were scraped off with a cell scraper, collected, and centrifuged at 800 × g for 3 min. The pellets were resuspended in ∼3 volumes of 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, subjected to ultrasonic treatment, and then centrifuged at 45,000 × g for 1 h at 4 °C. The supernatant, the cell extract, was kept at –80 °C. cN-II-mediated XMP and Guanine Nucleotide Synthesis—To follow XMP formation from Xao, the reaction mixtures contained 50 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 7.4, 1.4 mm [8-14C]Xao (9000 dpm/nmol), 2 mm IMP, 1 mm DTT, 10 mm MgCl2, 5 mm 2,3-BPG, and brain extract (2 mg of protein/ml) or LoVo cell extract (1 mg of protein/ml). To follow also guanine nucleotide synthesis, 2,3-BPG was substituted with ATP, which acts as cN-II activator and as substrate of GMP synthetase and nucleoside monophosphokinase and diphosphokinase. Modifications of the incubation mixtures are indicated in the figure legends. The reaction was started by the addition of crude extract. At different time intervals, the reaction was stopped by rapidly drying portions of 10 μl of the incubation mixture on PEI-cellulose-precoated thin-layer plastic sheets and a chromatogram was developed in n-propyl alcohol/NH3/trichloroacetic acid (100%)/H2O (75:0.7:5:20, v/v) to separate XMP, GMP, and GDP + GTP. In the separation, appropriate standards were used and detected as UV absorbing areas, which were excised and counted for radioactivity with 8 ml of scintillation liquid. IMPDH-mediated XMP and Guanine Nucleotides Synthesis—To follow XMP formation, the reaction mixtures contained 50 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 7.4, 2 mm [8-14C]IMP (3,000 dpm/nmol), 1 mm NAD+, 1 mm DTT, 20 mm KCl, and rat brain extract (2 mg of protein/ml) or LoVo cell extract (1 mg of protein/ml). When guanine nucleotide synthesis was also followed, 10 mm MgCl2, 5 mm ATP, and 5 mm glutamine were added. Modifications of the incubation mixture are indicated in the figure legends. The reaction was started by the addition of crude extract. At different time intervals, the reaction was stopped by rapidly drying portions of 10 μl of the incubation mixture on PEI-cellulose-precoated thin-layer plastic sheets and the chromatogram was developed in n-propyl alcohol/NH3/trichloroacetic acid (100%)/H2O (75:0.7:5: 20, v/v) to separate Xao, GMP, and GDP + GTP and with (NH4)2SO4 0.1 mm to identify XMP. In the separation, appropriate standards were used and detected as UV-absorbing areas, which were excised and counted for radioactivity with 8 ml of scintillation liquid. Incorporation of Xao and Analysis of Intracellular Metabolites in LoVo Cells—The experiments of Xao incorporation were performed in 35-mm culture plates (∼900,000 cells). Each plate was washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline, and 500 μl of serum-free DMEM with 10 mm glucose were added. LoVo cells were incubated in triplicate with 50 μm [8-14C]Xao (30,000 dpm/nmol). After the incubations, the cells were washed twice with 2 ml of cold physiological solution containing 1 mm Xao. 100 μl of 0.5 mm trichloroacetic acid were added to each plate, and cells were maintained at 4 °C. Subsequently, cells were harvested using a cell scraper and the suspension was heated at 70 °C for 30 min and then centrifuged at 12,000 × g for 2 min. The supernatants (∼100 μl) were all spotted on PEI-cellulose-precoated thin-layer plastic sheets. Xao, XMP, GMP, and GDP + GTP were separated and detected as described under “cN-II-mediated XMP and Guanine Nucleotide Synthesis.” Xao Is Phosphorylated by IMP, Not by ATP, in Rat Brain—A possible step, which would account for Xao salvage, is Xao phosphorylation as catalyzed by ATP-mediated cytosolic nucleoside kinases. However, at least in rat brain, this does not appear to be the case. Fig. 1 shows that the formation of XMP in the presence of 3.6 mm ATP, a physiological concentration (15.Traut T.W. Mol. Cell. Biochem. 1994; 140: 1-22Crossref PubMed Scopus (1274) Google Scholar), was preceded by a lag period. A possible explanation is that a phosphorylated catabolite of ATP, rather than ATP itself, acts as phosphate donor and that an enzyme distinct from nucleoside kinases catalyzes the reaction. The most likely candidates are IMP and cN-II, respectively. This hypothesis, which we had put forward in a previous study on purine salvage in rat brain (4.Barsotti C. Tozzi M.G. Ipata P.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 9865-9869Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar), is in accord with the following observations. (i) When ATP was substituted with IMP at equimolar concentration, the time course of XMP formation did not show any appreciable lag period and a larger amount of XMP was formed. (ii) At ATP concentrations as high as 100 μm (Fig. 1), compatible with the Km values of nucleoside kinases (16.Yamada Y. Goto H. Ogasawara N. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1980; 616: 199-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 17.Momparler R.L. Fischer G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1968; 243: 4298-4304Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), no Xao phosphorylation could be detected. Interestingly, at these relatively low concentrations, ATP breakdown follows the “adenosine pathway” with little if any IMP formation, whereas at a concentration of 3.6 mm, ATP breakdown follows the “IMP pathway,” with IMP itself as the major final product (13.Barsotti C. Ipata P.L. Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 2004; 36: 2214-2225Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). XMP was not further phosphorylated by the ATP present in the reaction mixture. We propose that Xao should be added to guanosine and inosine among those nucleosides that do not act as kinase substrates in mammals (7.Stone T.W. Simmonds H.A. Purine: Basic and Clinical Aspects. Kluwer Academic Publishers, Norwell, MA1991: 8-22Google Scholar, 18.Barsotti C. Pesi R. Felice F. Ipata P.L. Cell. Mol. Life Sci. 2003; 60: 786-793Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). The cN-II possesses both a phosphatase activity (IMP + H2O → inosine + Pi) and a purine nucleoside phosphotransferase activity (IMP + a purine-nucleoside → inosine + a purine-nucleoside monophosphate). Even though the molecular, kinetic, and regulatory properties of cN-II have been extensively studied in our laboratory (19.Pesi R. Turriani M. Allegrini S. Scolozzi C. Camici M. Ipata P.L. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 312: 75-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar, 20.Pesi R. Baiocchi C. Tozzi M.G. Camici M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1996; 1294: 191-194Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar), the physiological role of its phosphotransferase activity remains an enigma. The enzyme is responsible for the in vivo and in vitro activation of a series of antineoplastic and antiviral nucleoside analogs such as 2′-3′-dideoxyinosine, acyclovir, and 8-azaguanosine (21.Turriani M. Pesi R. Nardone A. Turchi G. Sgarrella F. Ipata P.L. Tozzi M.G. J. Biochem. Toxicol. 1994; 9: 51-57Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar), but its activity on intracellular natural nucleosides has not been documented. Our results suggest that the phosphotransferase activity of cN-II is responsible for the IMP-mediated Xao salvage in rat brain (the cN-II pathway). As shown in Table I, IMP-mediated Xao phosphorylation is strongly dependent on 2,3-BPG and ATP, the two allosteric activators of cN-II, and on Mg2+ ions. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 2, IMP and GMP were the best phosphate donors followed by UMP and CMP, in accord with the substrate specificity of the enzyme (19.Pesi R. Turriani M. Allegrini S. Scolozzi C. Camici M. Ipata P.L. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 312: 75-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Most probably, AMP acts as phosphate donor after being deaminated to IMP. Finally, the availability of bovine recombinant cN-II in our laboratory (11.Allegrini S. Pesi R. Tozzi M.G. Fiol C.J. Johnson R.B. Eriksson S. Biochem. J. 1997; 328: 483-487Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar) allowed us to show that indeed Xao is a substrate of this enzyme (data not shown).Table IIMP-mediated Xao phosphorylation requirementsAdditionXMP10 min30 minnmol/mg proteinComplete systemaThe complete system contained 1.4 mm [8-14C]Xao, 2 mm IMP, 5 mm 2,3-BPG, 10 mm MgCl2, 1mm DTT, 50 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 7.4, and rat brain extract (2 mg of protein/ml).2.247.57No 2,3-BPG0.641.77No MgCl20.291.75No 2,3-BPG, no MgCl20.450.65ATP instead of 2,3-BPG2.708.29a The complete system contained 1.4 mm [8-14C]Xao, 2 mm IMP, 5 mm 2,3-BPG, 10 mm MgCl2, 1mm DTT, 50 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 7.4, and rat brain extract (2 mg of protein/ml). Fig. 3 shows that, contrary to inosine, adenosine, and guanosine, Xao cannot be salvaged via this pathway. We notice that (ii) Xao is a substrate of rat brain PNP (12.Giorgelli F. Bottai C. Mascia L. Scolozzi C. Camici M. Ipata P.L. Biochim. Biophys. Kluwer Academic Publishers, Norwell, MA1991: 8-22Google Scholar) prevents any formation of AMP from adenine by adenine phosphoribosyltransferase, and the virtual absence of xanthine oxidase (25.Markley H.G. Faillace L.A. Mezey E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1973; 309: 23-31Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) prevents the further catabolic breakdown of xanthine to uric acid. We propose that any xanthine produced in the central nervous system via Xao phosphorolysis or guanine deamination is exported to other tissues and organs to be further catabolyzed. Xao Can Be Anabolyzed to GTP via the cN-II-mediated Pathway—The major source of XMP in mammalian cells is the NAD+-mediated reduction of IMP catalyzed by IMPDH, an enzyme targeted for human antiviral, immunosuppressive, and antineoplastic chemotherapy (26.Zimmermann A.G. Gu J.J. Laliberte J. Mitchell B.S. Prog. Nucleic Acids Res. Mol. Biol. 1998; 61: 181-209Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 27.Pankiewicz K.W. Patterson S.E. Black P.L. Jayaram H.N. Risal D. Goldstein B.M. Stuyver L.J. Schinazi R.F. Curr. Med. Chem. 2004; 11: 887-900Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Indeed, Fig. 4A shows that rat brain extract can efficiently convert IMP into XMP in the presence of NAD+. Dephosphorylation of XMP to Xao follows. However, as shown in Fig. 4B, the addition of glutamine and ATP in the reaction mixture considerably prevented XMP dephosphorylation. Rather, XMP was mainly converted to GMP, and GDP + GTP, via IMPDH, GMP synthetases, and nucleoside monophosphokinase and diphosphokinase. There is no doubt that this is the main pathway for the synthesis of guanine nucleotides in rat brain. Nevertheless, as shown in Fig. 5, the simple substitution of NAD+ with Xao resulted into XMP formation followed by GMP and GDP + GTP. In this pathway, cN-II bypasses IMPDH activity. Fig. 6 shows the interplay between the cN-II pathway and the IMPDH pathway for the synthesis of guanine nucleotides in rat brain. The in vitro efficiency of the cN-II pathway as judged from the amount of nucleotides formed ([XMP] + [guanine nucleotides]) at 60 min of incubation was ∼20% as that of the IMPDH pathway. We emphasize that, in our experimental conditions, ATP acts both as an allosteric activator of cN-II and a substrate of GMP synthetase and of nucleoside monophosphokinase and diphosphokinase.Fig. 5Time course of cN-II-mediated Xao salvage into guanine nucleotides catalyzed by rat brain extract. Moreover, whereas the IMPDH-mediated synthesis of guanyl compounds is considerably lowered by MPA, an inhibitor of the IMPDH (28.Eugui E.M. Almquist S.J. Muller C.D. Allison A.C. J. Immunol. 1991; 33: 161-173Google Scholar, 29.Eugui E.M. Mirkovich A. Allison A.C. Transplant. Proc. 1991; 23: 15-18PubMed Google Scholar), the cN-II-mediated synthesis was unaffected. The Xao salvage pathway proposed by us works in cultured cells. Fig. 8 shows that Xao can be transported into LoVo cells via an apparent equilibrative mechanism where it is converted into XMP and guanine nucleotides as just seen with cell extract (Fig. 7). The amount of purine nucleotide metabolites (XMP + GMP + GDP + GTP) formed intracellularly was ∼20% Xao transported.Fig. 8[8-14C]Xao incorporation into LoVo cells at different times. LoVo cells were incubated in triplicate with 50 μm [8-14C]Xao at the time intervals indicated as described under “Experimental Procedures.” Up to 90 min of incubation, nucleotide production was proportional to Xao uptake with r2 factor for a regression curve (least square) of 0.939.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Reversal of the in vitro antiproliferative effect exerted by IMPDH inhibitors has been observed with repletion of the guanine nucleotide pools as catalyzed by the HGPRT reaction (guanine + PRPP → GMP + PPi), which indirectly circumvents the action of IMPDH (Fig. 6). We propose that, in addition to this enzyme activity, also the phosphotransferase activity of cN-II on Xao might circumvent the activity of IMPDH. The IMPDH pathway may also be bypassed by the phosphotransferase activity of cN-II with IMP as phosphate donor and guanosine as phosphate acceptor (IMP + guanosine → GMP + inosine) (Fig. 6) (19.Pesi R. Turriani M. Allegrini S. Scolozzi C. Camici M. Ipata P.L. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1994; 312: 75-80Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Xao is present in human serum at a concentration comparable to that of adenosine (30.Niwa T. Takeda N. Yoshizumi H. Kidney Int. 1998; 53: 1801-1806Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). Its level specifically increases in patients with chronic renal failure (30.Niwa T. Takeda N. Yoshizumi H. Kidney Int. 1998; 53: 1801-1806Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). Moreover, as observed for other purine nucleosides (31.Phillis J.W. O'Regan M.H. Estevez A.Y. Song D. VanderHeide S.J. J. Neurochem. 1996; 67: 1525-1531Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar), its level might well increase in anoxic conditions since Xao accumulates in rat brain extract during GTP (13.Barsotti C. Ipata P.L. Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 2004; 36: 2214-2225Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar) and GMP (32.Torrecilla A. Marques A.F.P. Buscalioni R.D. Oliviera J.M.A. Teixeira N.A. Atencia E.A. Sillero M.A.G. Sillero A. J. Neurochem. 2001; 76: 1291-1307Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar) breakdown due to the presence of the so-called “ribose 1-phosphate recycling for nucleoside interconversion” (12.Giorgelli F. Bottai C. Mascia L. Scolozzi C. Camici M. Ipata P.L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1335: 16-22Crossref Scopus (20) Google Scholar). It is noteworthy that IMP, the preferred phosphate donor to Xao, accumulates during ATP breakdown in anoxic-like conditions (4.Barsotti C. Tozzi M.G. Ipata P.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 9865-9869Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 13.Barsotti C. Ipata P.L. Int. J. Biochem. Cell Biol. 2004; 36: 2214-2225Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). It might be speculated that, as it occurs for the other purine and pyrimidine nucleosides, the process of Xao salvage is particularly active during the reperfusion period. Moreover, Stoychev et al. (33.Stoychev G. Kierdaszuk B. Shugar D. Eur. J. Biochem. 2002; 269: 4048-4057Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar) have recently shown that, even at 8 mm Pi, phosphorolysis of Xao levels off at 83% conversion because of the equilibrium with the reverse synthetic pathway (33.Stoychev G. Kierdaszuk B. Shugar D. Eur. J. Biochem. 2002; 269: 4048-4057Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). Our data suggest that still unexplored pathways might exist for salvaging nucleosides, which might circumvent the activity of enzymes targeted for antiproliferative therapy.

Integrin αvβ3-mediated adhesion of hematopoietic cells to vitronectin results in activation of the Rho GTPases. Mutation of β3 tyrosine residue 747, previously shown to disrupt cell adhesion, results in sustained activation of Cdc42 and diminished Rac and Rho activity. We investigated the role of the hematopoietically restricted guanine nucleotide exchange factor Vav1 in αvβ3-mediated adhesion. We find that Vav1, a guanine nucleotide exchange factor for Rac and Rho, associates with αvβ3 upon cell adhesion to vitronectin and that this association requires β3 tyrosine phosphorylation. Expression of exogenous Vav1 demonstrates that Y160F, but not wild type or the Vav1Y174F mutant, inhibits Rac and Rho activation during αvβ3-mediated cell adhesion to vitronectin. Cells expressing Vav1Y160F exhibit a sustained Cdc42 activation similar to nonphosphorylatable β3 mutants. In addition, cytoskeletal reorganization and cell adhesion are severely suppressed in Vav1Y160F-transfected cells, and Vav1Y160F fails to associate with β3 integrins. Furthermore, Vav1 itself is selectively phosphorylated upon tyrosine 160 after αvβ3-mediated adhesion, and the association between Vav1 and β3 occurs in specific response to adhesion to substrate. These studies describe a phosphorylation-dependent association between β3 integrin and Vav1 which is essential for cell progression to a Rho-dominant phenotype during cell adhesion. Integrin αvβ3-mediated adhesion of hematopoietic cells to vitronectin results in activation of the Rho GTPases. Mutation of β3 tyrosine residue 747, previously shown to disrupt cell adhesion, results in sustained activation of Cdc42 and diminished Rac and Rho activity. We investigated the role of the hematopoietically restricted guanine nucleotide exchange factor Vav1 in αvβ3-mediated adhesion. We find that Vav1, a guanine nucleotide exchange factor for Rac and Rho, associates with αvβ3 upon cell adhesion to vitronectin and that this association requires β3 tyrosine phosphorylation. Expression of exogenous Vav1 demonstrates that Y160F, but not wild type or the Vav1Y174F mutant, inhibits Rac and Rho activation during αvβ3-mediated cell adhesion to vitronectin. Cells expressing Vav1Y160F exhibit a sustained Cdc42 activation similar to nonphosphorylatable β3 mutants. In addition, cytoskeletal reorganization and cell adhesion are severely suppressed in Vav1Y160F-transfected cells, and Vav1Y160F fails to associate with β3 integrins. Furthermore, Vav1 itself is selectively phosphorylated upon tyrosine 160 after αvβ3-mediated adhesion, and the association between Vav1 and β3 occurs in specific response to adhesion to substrate. These studies describe a phosphorylation-dependent association between β3 integrin and Vav1 which is essential for cell progression to a Rho-dominant phenotype during cell adhesion. The ultimate fate of integrin receptor complexes in adherent cells is their association with the actin cytoskeleton. Although enzymatically inactive, integrins sequester and/or recruit several classes of signaling and adaptor molecules to interaction domains within their cytoplasmic tails, forming functional signaling complexes. One purpose of these complexes is initiation of actin cytoskeletal linkage. In cells that circulate in the vasculature or in tissues during immune surveillance, the assembly of integrin signaling complexes is regulated to prevent unwarranted adhesion that could lead to inappropriate inflammation or thrombosis. We have previously defined one such regulated signal pathway in the αvβ3-mediated adhesion of hematopoietic cells (1Butler B. Williams M.P. Blystone S.D. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 5264-5270Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). Adhesion to vitronectin mediated by the integrin αvβ3 in hematopoietic cells requires phosphorylation of tyrosine 747 of the β3 cytoplasmic tail (2Blystone S.D. Williams M.P. Slater S.E. Brown E.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 28757-28761Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). This signaling event leads to activation of the small GTPase Rho in a Syk- and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase-dependent manner (1Butler B. Williams M.P. Blystone S.D. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 5264-5270Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). Rho activation is required for hematopoietic αvβ3-mediated adhesion and the corresponding formation of actin stress fibers. Phosphorylation of tyrosine 747 of β3 is also required for localization of the actin nucleation complex Arp2/3 to β3 adhesion sites (3Chandhoke S.K. Williams M. Schaefer E. Zorn L. Blystone S.D. J. Cell Sci. 2004; 117: 1431-1441Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Blockade of Rho activity or its downstream effector ROCK prevents both cell adhesion and the formation of actin stress fibers (1Butler B. Williams M.P. Blystone S.D. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 5264-5270Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 4Maekawa M. Ishizaki T. Boku S. Watanabe N. Fujita A. Iwamatsu A. Obinata T. Ohashi K. Mizuno K. Narumiya S. Science. 1999; 285: 895-898Crossref PubMed Scopus (1257) Google Scholar). It has been reported and is well characterized that activation of Rho family GTPases is involved in the formation of cytoskeletal structures. For example, Rho activation induces stress fiber formation, Rac activation induces lamellipodia formation, and Cdc42 activation induces filopodia formation (5Nobes C.D. Hall A. Cell. 1995; 81: 53-62Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3682) Google Scholar). Rho family GTPases execute their functions by regulating downstream effector proteins such as ROCK and PAK and are themselves subject to upstream regulation.
